comments.commentBody:
This is not President Obama's war; it was President Bush's.

But President Obama did promise us transparency, and how transparent do private contractors have to be?
Thankfully the national nightmare is over early this year.
Oddly, I am skeptical.

Invading Iraq for the wrong reasons is little reason to leave stupidly. Iraq matters: oil aside (it'll be years before Iraq can significantly increase exports,) they could fundamentally change the nature of a region by evolving a truly representative government. That's a big if, but imagine the impact on just one country--Iran.

I and my friends who served there are tired of this war as well; but the memories of those who didn't return with us and the hope of the future are enough for me to see this through. My great fear is whether this administration has the courage to do what's needed, even if that means peeling of a bumper sticker.

If you substitute "Afghanistan" for "Iraq" in the article it would still make sense.  So why are we, that is the Obama Administration,spending $100 billion in Afghanistan this year instead of following our example in Iraq? It sounds like the Vietnam fallacy with Obama in the role of LBJ waiting for some slick Nixon-like Republican like Newt Gingrich to tell us of a "secret plan" to end the war.  I guess you have to be over 50 and remember the tumultuous '60's.  Ah, so much promise, but so little vision.

This is not a proper or acceptable role for the State Department.  It is not our responsibility to act as the permanent policeman for Iraq.  Mr. Crocker's statement that we need to keep the Iraqi generals out of politics is one of the dumbest things I have ever heard from anyone, much less a former diplomat. How could we possibly do that? It is not our job to run Iraq and the sooner we are out of there, the better.
The "small army of contractors" is what bothers me about our leaving?!?!?

*IRAQ:76,495 casualties so far(From Pentagon statistics available on request)

> *US military occupation forces in Iraq under suffered four combat
casualties during the week ending August 17, as the official total since the March 2003 invasion rose to at least 76,495. That includes 35,401 dead and wounded from what the Pentagon classifies as "hostile"
causes and more than 41,094 dead and medically evacuated (as of July 31) from "non-hostile" causes.*

visit my website www.michaelmunk.com

This is just a bait and switch. The US will still be a military presence in Iraq, but not THE US military. Boy does this make me cynical!
Aimlow Joe was here.
http://www.aimlow.com

What WILL happen when there's a coup; will they march out in a fighting retreat like the Greek mercs did in the same area of the world in 401 BC (Xenophon, "Anabasis)? Bush et al. never did know a lick of history when they rolled in in 2003, why get it right now?
In other words, now the USA fights its wars with armies of mercenaries. Why doesn't the NYT reflect on this obvious, highly-disturbing point?

BR confuses me.  We have been spending excess funds since 1973 (circa Jimmy Carter)  and still do not have those alternate, renewable, carbon free fuels.  Under what thought process do we need to spend more money, for a non-existent theory?  With all brain power in our over-reported universities, colleges, and research centers,  why does it take more money?   Energy center in Boulder, Colorado came out with much bally-hooed energy (sun) powered vehicle for 2 persons,  when a golf cart gives same uncomfortable, out in the elements ride  for lot less money.  We need the carbon molecule for plastics, test equipment, food, fuel, clothing, shoes, and too many other products, and will be using coal, gas, and oil for next century.   Get head straight, and realize that every "green job"  forces  4 to 7 workers to become unemployed, at excessive cost. Simple research will prove that statement.

Finally!!!
wow, 7 years, 3 and 1/2 months, over 4,400 US lives lost, thousands of permanently maimed humans, hundreds of thousands of innocent Iraq men women and children dead, trillion dollars borrowed.....
.....MISSION ACCOMPLISHED.
I wonder if bushie boy is celebrating with his flight suit tonight?

But we are still there and that is not enough...we need to be gone.

You know what comes to mind? That there's no way out. Period. Only an idiot could fail to see how expensive this war/police action/invasion/whatever has been to the United States in lives, money and to our liberties (remember when the whole country was a "free speech zone"?).

And only a bigger idiot would fail to see the enormous opportunity to even more-fully damage the U.S. by inciting us to invade all over again. Doesn't matter where: Iraq, Afghanistan, Pakistan, just get our uberpatriots fired up and watch them force us all off the cliff.

I'll believe the US is leaving Iraq when I see video of all the military bases being blown up. I'm not holding my breath.

Funny how there's always money for endless wars.

Contractors?  Under the Obama -yes, Obama- administration?  What dastardly influence does the Antichrist Dick Cheney have over him?  Can we still blame Cheney nearly EIGHTEEN MONTHS on something still?

Hello Americans... close you eyes and imagine the fabulous wealth that the early Oil Barons in the 1920s and 30s enjoyed. Now imagine how much that has grown and how many politicians that buys. Answer - all of them.
China out-grows, out-works and out-saves you every day. And you truly haven't got a snow ball's chance in hell of catching up to them. Want to know how to ruin a great country in one century - get em hooked on Oil....and the notion of "protecting" America's oil interests abroad.
As we say down here at Big Oil..."we didn't get big by caring".
You will see more Iraqis hating Americans, more terrorist, and all the goodwill thrown out the window once we handover Iraq to a private army. I'm very surprised at President Obama who I admire.

Just how stupid has this administration become to it's supporters? While trumpeting that our military presence in Iraq is now withdrawn, it seeks a hand puppet, a distraction, that State has taken over with mercenaries who can do a better job at training police and military in a war zone than....our military!!! Many of us were outraged at the outsourcing of the military to the likes of Blackwater and others who double and tripled taxed the taxpayers by recruiting tax payer funded military training and paying double or more to a corporate military who hired them away.

But w;hat or how the hell is the State Department equipped to manage a privatized military to ensure the aftermath of withdrawal? Perhaps the saving of this surreal universe is that Hilliary Clinton happens to head State. As a waning Obama supporter, I long for that leadership that does much more than to respond to the hard right media machine that trumps his every move and dictates his limp, confusing, redefining and poll driven responses. OK, Mr. Obama, explain to us how State can deliver a stability that the military left unaccomplished in Iraq.

And what is the exact purpose of these "civilian contractors" but to fight the war under another name and at greater expense?

Just what is the purpose of this war, anyway, and why is it more important than healing our wounded nation?

Great move: Bring in the Mercs. Private armies for private causes and private gains.
Interested readers should check out H.R. 4986 (2008), and George Bush's corresponding Signing Statement of Jan. 28, 2008. Pay close attention to the 4 sections addressed by the Signing Statement and what those sections were dealing with (841-Contractor fraud; 846-contractor whistleblower protection; 1079-intelligence assessments; and 1222-permanent bases). What we have now is: rampant fraud; no whistleblower protection; zero intelligence assessments; and plenty of permanent bases.
Also check out H.R. 2346 (2009) and Obama's Signing Statement, and what the specified sections deal with (hint: World Bank and IMF). New loyalties, same politics.

I am sure I will be attacked by all other commentators.......so here I go!

I voted for Obama.....and I continue to support him. By hook or by crook. He is more than A great President. He is a born leader.He is a diplomat. He inspires. He will prevail by leading........a better solution in Iraq and Afghanistan.

For America to leave and not have any back up for the civilians who supported us would be slaughter. It happened at least one time before. Viet Nam.

I saw it.

Your editorial does not come out and say it directly, but the tone suggests that BP should pay up to "restore the Gulf" - whatever that means.  This is dead wrong.  BP should pay up to clean up the damage caused by its oil spill, and compensate people directly harmed by the spill.  It should not pay anything beyond this, certainly not to fix things caused by decades of problems not related to any of BP's activities.  Your implication that BP - a private, shareholder owned corporation, including many U.S. shareholders - should somehow become the piggy bank writing checks to meet some other broader political agenda, is wrong headed and would send a completely wrong message to business from this administration.

Gail, isn't this how Roman Senators bought their seats when they still had a functioning democracy. Bread and circus. The ideals of egalitarianism were 1,700 years in the future. Although we seem to be losing this ideal lately in the US with tax cuts to the wealthy and corporate takeover of the Supreme Court. If the right can run affable faux middle class front-men like Bush W., Reagan Palin, etc. we on the left can run against type as well(as long as he's up to his elite bracket paying higher taxes, I wonder if anyone asked him about the expiring Bush tax cuts)
If Johnston embodies the American dream, I shudder to think what the nightmare might be.
